bibl.title: Letter from Merritte W. Ireland to S.S. Goldwater, April 11, 1935

div1.p: Ireland recommends Truby for a hospital position, describing his character and experience.

div1.head: Letter from Merritte W. Ireland to S.S. Goldwater, April 11, 1935
div1.opener:
1870 Wyoming Avenue,
Washington, D. C.
April 11, 1935.
Doctor S. S. Goldwater,
Commissioner of Hospitals,
Municipal Building,
New York, N. Y.
My dear Doctor Goldwater:
div1.p:
General Truby has told me of his visit to you last week and has asked
me just to make a statement to you of my knowledge of his work in the Medical
Corps of the Army. I am glad to do this because, during all of his career,
General Truby has occupied a prominent place in the work of the Corps.

It is not well known but it is a fact that young Truby was a warm per-
sonal friend of Walter Reed's. He was with him in Cuba when the experiments
were being carried on that proved the method of transmission of yellow fever
and when Lazear died Walter Reed wanted Truby to join the yellow fever board
to take Lazear's place but conditions arose which made that impossible.

I have known General Truby intimately for years and know of his valuable
service. At one time he was the Chief Health Officer of the Panama Canal
Zone, which, as you know, is a most responsible position. He carried on his
work down there in a creditable way. During the War he rendered splendid
service as one of the General Inspectors in the Office of the Surgeon General.
After the War he became the Chief Medical Officer of the Air Service and, with
his rare talents for organization, accomplished a great deal in organizing
and solidifying this new service in the Medical Corps. During my service as
Surgeon General he commanded the Letterman General Hospital at San Francisco,
Calif. His administration of this large hospital was everything that could
be desired. He has a very clear insight into the management of hospitals and
proved himself an expert as a builder. He was also the Chief Surgeon of the
Philippine Division for a tour and Surgeon of the Corps Area at Governors
Island, N. Y. In both places he proved his worth as an administrator.

General Truby's last service during the time I was Surgeon General was
as my Executive Officer. I selected him because he had the confidence of the
Corps and was known to be a man of rare judgment. Shortly after I retired,
my successor had General Truby appointed a brigadier General and assigned to
command the Army Medical Center in this district. I have watched his work
out there with a great deal of admiration. He has brought the administration
of that great center to a high degree of efficiency and has again proven him-
self a master in construction and in beautifying the reservation.

General Truby is a gentleman of pleasing personality, thoroughly loyal
and dependable. I have the deepest confidence that he would be a comfort to
any one who could use his rare talents.
div1.closer:
Very sincerely yours, (Sgd.) M. W. Ireland
M. W. Ireland
Major General, U.S. Army, Retired. *ML
